ai-mn119:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn119:2.1_0: Then after the meal, on return from alms-round, several senior mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:
ai-mn119:2.3_0: how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
ai-mn119:2.4_0: But their conversation was left unfinished. Then the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the pavilion.
ai-mn119:2.4_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-mn119:2.5_0: and told the mendicants what had happened.
ai-mn119:2.6_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
ai-mn119:2.7_0: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:
ai-mn119:2.9_0: how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.’
ai-mn119:2.10_0: This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
ai-mn119:3.1_0: “And how, mendicants, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-mn119:4.1_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-mn119:4.2_0: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
ai-mn119:4.3_0: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
ai-mn119:4.6_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling physical processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling physical processes.’
ai-mn119:4.7_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:4.8_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:4.9_0: That’s how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:5.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know: ‘I am walking.’ When standing they know: ‘I am standing.’ When sitting they know: ‘I am sitting.’ And when lying down they know: ‘I am lying down.’
ai-mn119:5.2_0: Or they understand it in whatever manner the body,
ai-mn119:5.3_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:5.4_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:5.5_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:6.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl, and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
ai-mn119:6.2_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:6.3_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:6.4_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:7.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
ai-mn119:7.2_0: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
ai-mn119:7.3_0: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as
ai-mn119:7.4_0: fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice.
ai-mn119:7.5_0: But a person with good eyesight standing on the bank of the eye,
ai-mn119:7.6_0: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’
ai-mn119:7.7_0: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. ...
ai-mn119:7.8_0: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
ai-mn119:7.9_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:7.10_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:7.11_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:8.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
ai-mn119:8.2_0: ‘There is this body, water, fire, or air.’
ai-mn119:8.3_0: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into portions.
ai-mn119:8.4_0: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
ai-mn119:8.5_0: ‘There is this body, water, fire, or air.’
ai-mn119:8.6_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:8.7_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:8.8_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:9.1_0: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse thrown in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn119:9.2_0: Then they arranged their body, thinking:
ai-mn119:9.3_0: ‘This body is produced by the teaching and training.’
ai-mn119:9.4_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:9.5_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:9.6_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:10.1_0: Or suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
ai-mn119:10.2_0: Then they arranged their body, thinking:
ai-mn119:10.3_0: ‘This body is produced by the teachings and has developed so that it is when developed.’
ai-mn119:10.5_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:11-14.1_0: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And they had been reduced by sinews ...
ai-mn119:11-14.2_0: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews ...
ai-mn119:11-14.3_0: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews ...
ai-mn119:11-14.4_0: Bones without sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull ...
ai-mn119:11-14.5_0: Then they arranged their body, thinking:
ai-mn119:11-14.6_0: ‘This body is produced by the teaching and training.’
ai-mn119:11-14.8_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:15-17.1_0: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn119:15-17.2_0: White bones, the color of shells ...
ai-mn119:15-17.3_0: she had been reduced with bones,
ai-mn119:15-17.5_0: Then they arranged their body, thinking:
ai-mn119:15-17.6_0: ‘This body is produced by the teachings and has developed so that it is when developed.’
ai-mn119:15-17.9_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:18.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-mn119:18.2_0: In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
ai-mn119:18.3_0: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
ai-mn119:18.4_0: In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
ai-mn119:18.4_1: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
ai-mn119:18.7_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:19.1_0: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption ...
ai-mn119:19.2_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
ai-mn119:19.2_1: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
ai-mn119:19.3_0: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water.
ai-mn119:19.3_1: There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from the north to the south.
ai-mn119:19.3_2: And the heavens don’t provide enough rain when needed.
ai-mn119:19.3_3: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
ai-mn119:19.4_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
ai-mn119:19.6_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:20.1_0: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
ai-mn119:20.2_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
ai-mn119:20.3_0: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
ai-mn119:20.4_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
ai-mn119:20.6_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:21.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-mn119:21.2_0: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind.
ai-mn119:21.2_1: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
ai-mn119:21.3_0: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
ai-mn119:21.4_0: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
ai-mn119:21.5_0: Then, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they give up the lay life.
ai-mn119:21.6_0: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn119:21.7_0: That is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
ai-mn119:22.1_0: Anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
ai-mn119:22.2_0: Anyone who brings into their mind the great ocean includes all of the streams that run down into it.
ai-mn119:22.3_0: In the same way, anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
ai-mn119:23.1_0: When a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-mn119:23.2_0: Suppose a person were to throw a heavy stone ball on a mound of wet clay.
ai-mn119:23.4_0: Would that heavy stone ball find an entry into that mound of wet clay?”
ai-mn119:23.6_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-mn119:24.1_0: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log.
ai-mn119:24.2_0: Then a person with good eyesight were to come along, saying:
ai-mn119:24.3_0: ‘I will create a fire and produce heat.’
ai-mn119:24.5_0: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
ai-mn119:24.7_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-mn119:25.1_0: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, empty and hollow.
ai-mn119:25.2_0: Then a man comes along with water,
ai-mn119:25.4_0: Wouldn’t that person get out from the water?”
ai-mn119:25.6_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-mn119:26.1_0: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.
ai-mn119:26.2_0: Suppose a person were to throw a light ball of string at a door-panel made entirely of hardwood.
ai-mn119:26.4_0: Would that light ball of string find an entry into that door-panel made entirely of hardwood?”
ai-mn119:26.6_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.
ai-mn119:27.1_0: Suppose there was a green, sappy log.
ai-mn119:27.2_0: Then a person with good eyesight were to come along, saying:
ai-mn119:27.3_0: ‘I will create a fire and produce heat.’
ai-mn119:27.5_0: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
ai-mn119:27.7_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.
ai-mn119:28.1_0: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-mn119:28.2_0: Then a man comes along with water,
ai-mn119:28.4_0: Wouldn’t that person get out from the water?”
ai-mn119:28.6_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get hold of them.
ai-mn119:29.1_0: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-mn119:29.2_0: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-mn119:29.3_0: If a strong man was to pour it on any side, would water pour out?”
ai-mn119:29.5_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-mn119:30.1_0: Suppose there was a square, walled lotus pond on level ground, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-mn119:30.2_0: If a strong man was to open the wall on any side, would water pour out?”
ai-mn119:30.4_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-mn119:31.1_0: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
ai-mn119:31.2_0: Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
ai-mn119:31.3_0: In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-mn119:32.1_0: You can expect ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.
ai-mn119:33.1_0: They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.
ai-mn119:34.1_0: They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.
ai-mn119:35.1_0: They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
ai-mn119:36.1_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-mn119:37.1_0: He wields the many kinds of psychic power.
ai-mn119:37.1_1: multiplying themselves and becoming one again ...
ai-mn119:37.1_2: as far as the Brahmā realm.
ai-mn119:38.1_0: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far. ...
ai-mn119:39.1_0: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind. ...
ai-mn119:39.2_0: mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
ai-mn119:39.3_0: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.
ai-mn119:39.4_0: mind with hate as “mind with hate”,
ai-mn119:39.5_0: and mind without hate as “mind without hate”;
ai-mn119:39.6_0: mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”,
ai-mn119:39.7_0: and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”;
ai-mn119:39.12_0: mind that is not supreme as “mind that is not supreme”,
ai-mn119:39.13_0: and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”;
ai-mn119:39.14_0: mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”,
ai-mn119:39.15_0: and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”,
ai-mn119:39.17_0: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
ai-mn119:40.1_0: They recollect many kinds of past lives.
ai-mn119:40.1_1: There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-mn119:41.1_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-mn119:42.1_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn119:43.1_0: You can expect these ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.”
ai-mn119:43.2_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn119:43.3_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn119:43.4_0: The ninth section on mindfulness of the body is finished.
